question: The pilot of a light twin engine aircraft has calculated a 4 000 m service ceiling, based on the forecast general conditions for the flight and a Take-off Mass of 3 250 kg. If the Take-off Mass is 3 000 kg, the service ceiling will be:
optionA: higher than 4 000 m.
optionB: only a new performance analysis will determine if the service ceiling is higher or lower than 4 000 m.
optionC: unchanged, equal to 4 000 m.
optionD: less than 4 000 m.

question: Consider a glide with all engines off. Initial conditions are zero wind and attitude of the airplane gives maximum range. A headwind arises and initially the aircraft attitude is not changed. After some time has passed:
optionA: the glide range increases when the CL is reduced.
optionB: the glide range remains the same when CL is reduced.
optionC: the glide range remains maximum when CL remains the same.
optionD: the glide range decreases when the CL is reduced.

question: Consider a climb with a piston engine airplane. What will happen to the fuel flow if the pilot maintains the same power setting?

optionD: With increasing altitude air density decreases, therefore less fuel is required for combustion, so the fuel flow decreases.

optionD: increases the power required.
